As illustrated in Fig. 6(f) and 6(g), our analysis extends to examining the token length with the Vicuna-7B tokenizerÂ [5] when tables are encoded in HTML format. We found that the tokenizer does not incorporate HTML tags such as <tâ€‹d>expectationğ‘¡ğ‘‘<td>, <tâ€‹r>expectationğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ<tr>, and <tâ€‹h>expectationğ‘¡â„<th> as individual tokens. Although incorporating these tags as special tokens slightly increases the vocabulary size, it significantly reduces the number of required input tokens.
Typically, open-sourced MLLMsÂ [16, 13] integrate vision queries and text queries by concatenating them before feeding them into the LLMs.
Consequently, comparing the length of text tokens with the length of vision tokens becomes feasible when tables are represented in both image and text formats.
As shown in TableÂ 2, the length of vision tokens varies widely, ranging from 32 to 1445. It is observed that the efficiency of image-formatted tables significantly decreases compared to those text-formatted with special tokens when the length of a vision query exceeds 1,000 tokens.

Comparative analysis is conducted on MLLMs, including commercial models such as Gemini-ProV333gemini-pro-vision and gemini-pro are employed for MLLM and LLM, respectively.Â [23] and GPT-4V444gpt-4-vision-preview and gpt-4-1106-preview are employed for MLLMs and LLM, respectively. For gpt-4-vision-preview, we adopt â€˜autoâ€™ as a detail optionÂ [1], and several open-source models as outlined in TableÂ 2.
Since SPHINX-MoE and SPHINX-v2 have not been published, we exploited huggingface models555https://huggingface.co/Alpha-VLLM/LLaMA2-Accessory/tree/main/finetune/mm/SPHINX.
To examine the capabilities of their underlying LLMs on TableQA, Vicuna-7B-v1.5Â [5], Vicuna-13B-v1.5Â [5], Gemini-ProÂ [23], GPT-3.5, and GPT-4Â [2] are evaluated by feeding them HTML-encoded tables as input.
We also employ two-stage inference methods. We extract the HTML of tables using MLLMs and then conduct the QA task with LLMs where these methods are denoted as GPT-4V â†’â†’\rightarrow GPT-4 and Gemini-ProV â†’â†’\rightarrow Gemini-Pro. We expect this to reveal the correlation between textual and visual modalities.

references:
Two-stage inference leads to significant performance enhancements within the same vision input on both GPT and Gemini families. Despite such enhancements, it is evident that the performance still falls short compared to when text input is used.
While it might be feasible to conduct experiments extracting HTML and answers through prompt tuning in the single MLLM, unfortunately, we were unable to obtain results in our desired format.
Employing TEDsÂ [29] evaluation metric, we compare the MLLMsâ€™ performance on TSR with that of the state-of-the-art (SoTA) modelÂ [8].
For a fair comparison, we utilize the SoTA model trained only on PubTabNetÂ [28], which can be regarded as a held-out dataset for TableVQA-Bench.
As shown in TableÂ 4, the SoTA model usually performs better than MLLMs.
These findings indicate that MLLMs exhibit limitations in efficiently extracting information from visual tables.
